Posts.Content: biscottigirl wrote: Hi all, (If I should post this question somewhere else, please advise.)  I had a node negative, er/pr+ her- 1.2 cm breast cancer tumor in my armpit not in my breast (aka ectopic axillary bc) and the path report said vascular space invasion present.  They want to radiate my armpit but that will increase my risk of lymphedema since I had axillary dissectionn, so I'm not jumping on board unless radiation is known to significantly increase chances of survival.  It seems radiation is for local recurrance and if it's in the armpit, there's not so much breast tissue there so it doesn't seem to be a big risk of recurrance there.  At the same time, the lumpectomy was done 60 days ago so any microscopic cancer cells left have already had a chance to start duplicating and get in my system, esp. because it said vascular space invasion present.  So doesn't that mean I'm at greater risk for systemic mets and less risk for local recurrance? In which case, it seems like chemo (if oncotype results show high risk) and hormone tx would have the most effect, even without radiation???  Can someone please help me understand why I'd still want radiation? Thanks, biscottigirl Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radiation local vs. Vascular Space Invasion present biscottigirl Binney4
